        <description><p>Publisher Grey Box and developer Tequila Works announced it will release version 1.0.2 on the Nintendo Switch on Monday, February 19.&nbsp;</p>
<p >&nbsp;<img  src="/articles_media/images/rime-1.jpg"  width="640"  height="360"/></p>
<p>Read the complete patch notes for version 1.0.2 below:</p>
<ul>
<li>Increased visual fidelity, bloom and post-processing</li>
<li>Sharpened image resolution</li>
<li>Opening Cinematics visually improved</li>
<li>Fixed possible stage exploits that would enable players to skip parts of the stages</li>
<li>Increased texture quality in specific areas</li>
<li>Increased view distance</li>
<li>Fixed an issue with foliage density, shadows, and render distances</li>
<li>Updated texture mipmaps for the Fox</li>
<li>Improved global mipmaps</li>
<li>Improved shadow distance and quality</li>
<li>Fixed instances of foliage pops</li>
<li>Stabilized FPS</li>
<li>Optimized the Boys cape and hair physics</li>
<li>Rebuilt streaming volumes</li>
<li>Fixed an issue that allowed you to see outside of the map in later stages.</li>
<li>Updated lighting to prevent bleed through</li>
<li>Updated the quality of trees in earlier stages where they would display poorly.</li>
</ul>

        <description><p>Crazy Monkey Studios announced&nbsp;<em>Guns, Gore &amp; Cannoli 2</em> will launch for Windows PC via Steam on March 2. The developer also announced the game is also in development for the Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4 and Xbox One.</p>
<p>View the launch trailer below:</p>
<p ></p>
<p>Here is an overview of the game:</p>
<p><span>Welcome to the 1940&rsquo;s. Europe is being torn apart by the war, the USA is preparing for battle and the mob does business as usual. Only this time they went too far, even for Vinnie&rsquo;s standards.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><span>Prepare yourself to go to war after you make a shocking discovery about what actually happened during the end-stage of the Thugtown Massacre from <em>Guns, Gore &amp; Cannoli 1</em>.</span><br /><br /><strong>Story</strong><br /><span>1944, the war in Europe is entering its final stage. 15 years have passed since Vinnie survived the Thugtown Massacre. But now, some loose ends start crawling out of the past, dragging Vinnie as far as the European battlefield of World War 2. Find out who is chasing Vinnie around like a dog, turning all his friends into foes.</span><br /><br /><strong>Key features:</strong><br /><br /><span><em>Guns, Gore &amp; Cannoli 2</em> continues the rich, engaging gangster story of the first game and includes all the fast paced action you&rsquo;ve come to love, we made the best even better, with:</span><br /><br /></p>
<ul  class="bb_ul">
<li><span>Upgraded character mobility -&nbsp;</span>Vinnie has received a massive upgrade in his mobility features. 360 aiming, double jumping, kicking, jump-kicking, dodge rolls, somersaults, dual guns and a weapon wheel.<br /><br /></li>
<li><span>Campaign mode -&nbsp;</span>Guns, Gore &amp; Cannoli 2 features a full single or multiplayer campaign mode, packed with action, humor and animated cutscenes.<br /><br /></li>
<li><span>Rich environments -&nbsp;</span>We pushed our artists to the limits to produce the best immersive, atmospheric backgrounds, smoothest animations, and coolest special effects, setting a new benchmark for 2D games. Look for opportunities to bring down walls, explode barrels, drop crates on top of enemies, blow up cars and even kick your enemies through doors. Enjoy watching the corpses of your enemies fly through the air like ragdolls after you blast them away with your rocket launcher.<br /><br /></li>
<li><span>Immersive world and period -&nbsp;</span>Walk around in the European battlefields of World War 2. Every level of Guns, Gore &amp; Cannoli breathes the 1940&rsquo;s. Every inch of the game is like a picture straight from the second World War era. The cars, the furniture, the speakeasy clubs, the music, the propaganda posters, the streets and the weaponry reflect the turbulent time that the 1940&rsquo;s were.<br /><br /></li>
<li><span>Online and local Co-op mode -&nbsp;</span>You don&rsquo;t want to die alone in the trenches? Well round up a platoon of 4 players and get blasting. Play as Vinnie in the solo campaign, or with up to 3 friends together while fighting through hordes of Nazis, zombies, monster, gangsters, cops, soldiers, tanks, submarines... in this all-new and incredibly fun arcade-style co-op action game. Teamwork is essential to surviving waves of enemy goons.<br /><br /></li>
<li><span>Humor -&nbsp;</span>&lsquo;War is hell&rsquo; unless you are Vinnie Cannoli and you turn every problem into a cynical joke, blurting out one-liners and snappy comments after a nice, juicy kill. Guns, Gore &amp; Cannoli 2 will be a fun experience, not only to play but also to watch. Funny one-liners, screaming deaths, comical dialogs and hilarious enemies make you play this violent kill-simulator with a smirky grin on your face.</li>
</ul>

        <title><![CDATA[A Look Back at the Birth & Rise of the Asian-English Market on Vita]]></title>
        <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/VGChartz/~3/xLfKGyqBGUg/</link>
        <category><![CDATA[Analysis]]></category>
        <category><![CDATA[Charts]]></category>
        <category><![CDATA[Industry]]></category>
        <dc:creator><![CDATA[Adam Cartwright]]></dc:creator>
        <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.vgchartz.com/story/272598/a-look-back-at-the-birth-amp-rise-of-the-asian-english-market-on-vita/</guid>
        <description><p>The PlayStation Vita, somewhat like the PSP before it, suffered from a popularity imbalance. Despite being a niche product in western markets, it found a strong footing in its homeland of Japan, where lifestyles are better suited to handheld gaming. This approach has extended to mainline Asia, where the Vita has been somewhat of a success in places like Hong Kong and Singapore, maintaining a steady flow of releases and decent hardware sales.</p>
<p>This has led to a window of opportunity for certain publishers. Japanese-developed titles make up the majority of the Vita's library but some of these have been unsuitable for western markets, often by virtue of some questionably lewd elements that wouldn't sit well with western rating boards. As a compromise, these publishers have been able to tap into the Asian market (where multiple countries have English as a dominant language) and release physical carts with English subtitles, which have rapidly become hugely popular on import sites like <a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/">Play-Asia</a>. In addition to these, some games which were digital-only in the west managed to get physical English releases in Asia, due to the stronger market there.</p>
<p>It's these titles that I'll be looking at in this article - how the market originated, how it has flourished over the years, and where it's at currently. It's something that has grown with the console; I don't remember it being anywhere near as prevalent prior to the Vita's launch and as such it's easy to believe that the handheld played a big part in shaping the market into what it is today.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>2014 - The (Sword Art) Online Birth of the Asian-English Release</strong></span></p>
<p>The Asian-English market was (sort of) alive and well from the date of the Vita's launch in the region in 2011, where a number of titles like&nbsp;<em>Disgaea</em> and&nbsp;<em>Uncharted</em> were available alongside the brand new hardware. This is something that would continue throughout the console's life and isn't particularly worth noting here, as these games were generally available in physical English format in Europe and North America too.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-12.png"/></p>
<p>The first time the market truly offered something different was in 2012, with the launch of <em>Dokuro</em>. The 2D puzzle-platformer was released in Japan in July and on the same date an <a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/dokuro-multi-language-edition/13/704v6t">Asian release</a> happened too, with English subtitles. It was basically a precursor to the digital western version which landed in October. A similar thing happened with <a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/orgarhythm/13/704zh7"><em>Orgarhythm</em></a> in August, which offered a physical cart in Asia that would play in English if your system was set to that language, but was only distributed digitally overseas by XSEED, making it a key early title early on which was popular with importers.</p>
<p>There was then a long gap until the March 2014 release of&nbsp;the remastered&nbsp;<em>Final Fantasy X</em> games, which would become the next titles to follow this lead. In Japan, they'd released as two separate carts (one for&nbsp;<em>X,</em>&nbsp;one for&nbsp;<em>X-2</em>) but in the west it was announced that only&nbsp;<em>X</em> would be on the cart and&nbsp;<em>X-2</em> would be a download code - not great news for anyone with a small memory card, or even those who just like to preserve their games. Enter the Asian-English release which had&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/final-fantasy-x-2-hd-remaster-english/13/707g9z">X-2</a></em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/final-fantasy-x-2-hd-remaster-english/13/707g9z"> as its own cart</a>,&nbsp;making it a perfect compromise for anyone unsatisfied with the product on offer in the west.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-11.jpg"/></p>
<p>This was just the first insight into the market, though, as Bandai-Namco would soon go one better in May with&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/sword-art-online-hollow-fragment-chinese-english-sub/13/707jlr">Sword Art Online: Hollow Fragment</a></em>. The popular anime title was released in English a full three months before a <a  href="https://gematsu.com/2014/07/sword-art-online-hollow-fragment-european-release-date-announced">western version was available</a>, suggesting that the localization had been greenlit on the basis of prospective Asian sales alone. It was hugely popular among importers (despite the fact that it was hampered by an <a  href="http://www.siliconera.com/2014/09/10/sword-art-online-hollow-fragment-death-localization/">awful localization</a>) and would be the first title to truly usher in the new era of games being translated for the Asian-English market thanks to its success (it shifted&nbsp;<a  href="http://nichegamer.com/2014/10/14/sword-art-online-hollow-fragment-has-shipped-over-400k-units-worldwide/">400k copies worldwide</a>).</p>
<p>The rest of the year was made up of a fairly standard slate of titles that were already available from European and North American publishers, such as&nbsp;<em>Senran Kagura: Shinovi Versus</em> and&nbsp;<em>Tales of Hearts R.</em> There was<em>&nbsp;</em>one extra standout -&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/soul-sacrifice-delta-english/13/707qyx">Soul Sacrifice Delta</a></em>, the expanded version of 2013's hunting action game, which landed digitally in the west but received a physical print in Asia. While Sony was winding down on the console, it was nice to see the publisher provide this option for gamers and is something that would be follow up on in 2015. It was clear that this was something other publishers were rapidly jumping on board with too.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>2015 - The Second Wave &amp; an Ever-Increasing Market</strong></span></p>
<p>2015 would see a larger variety of titles making use of the Vita's popularity in Asia in this fashion; ones which were either digital-only in the west or only had very limited releases.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-10.jpg"/></p>
<p>The first noteworthy game of the year was&nbsp;<em>HTOL#NIQ: The Firefly Diary</em>, an artsy puzzle-platformer from Nippon Ichi Software that was localized by the overseas subsidiary NIS America, who only provided very low quantities of a <a  href="https://store.nisamerica.com/htol-niq-the-firefly-diary-limited-edition">Limited Edition</a>&nbsp;in North America (and nothing in Europe, where it was digital-only). An <a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/htolniq-the-firefly-diary-english-sub/13/708fpr">Asian-English</a> version therefore satisfied this gap in the market, even if it became obsolete a few years later when a dual-pack including&nbsp;<em>Yomawari</em> became available on the same cart.</p>
<p>Other publishers began to make use of Asian-English publishing too. For example, Koei-Tecmo's&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/deception-iv-the-nightmare-princess-english-sub/13/708wmt">Deception IV: The Nightmare Princess</a>&nbsp;</em>was a digital-only western affair despite its prequel&nbsp;<em>Blood Ties</em> being available at retail. Even Sony itself provided an Asian-English physical version of its fantastic JRPG&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/oreshika-tainted-bloodlines-english/13/708ji5">Oreshika: Tainted Bloodlines</a>,</em> which has become a popular collector's item in recent years due to its rarity.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-8.jpg"/></p>
<p>Given Bandai-Namco's success with&nbsp;<em>Sword Art Online</em>, it was unsurprising to see other publishers quickly follow suit. Compile Heart's&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/moe-chronicle-chinese-english-sub/13/708k51">Moe Chronicle</a></em> found its way across in May of 2015, although unlike&nbsp;<em>SAO</em>&nbsp;it didn't manage to find its way west at all due to heavy fanservice (although a <a  href="http://store.steampowered.com/app/638160/agecheck">2017 Steam release</a> managed to avoid ratings board requirements). Oddly, Sony&nbsp;<a  href="http://www.siliconera.com/2015/04/12/moe-chronicle-english-version-moero-chronicle-set-may-release/">appeared to have a hand</a> in bringing this one across, something that was <a  href="http://www.siliconera.com/2015/09/17/moero-crystal-will-be-localized-into-english/">alleged to be happening again</a> with its sequel&nbsp;<em>Moero Crystal</em>&nbsp;but this hasn't materialized as of the date of this article.</p>
<p>The remaining months of the year would see three more games which were digital-only in the west receive Asian-English versions. The first of these was&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/resident-evil-revelations-2-multi-language/13/708xwx">Resident Evil Revelations 2</a> -&nbsp;</em>a port funded by Sony but published by Capcom (who had been largely absent on Vita throughout its life). The second was&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/samurai-warriors-4-ii-english/13/70927v">Samurai Warriors 4-II</a></em>, which was somewhat of a surprise given that its prequel,&nbsp;<em>Samurai Warriors 4,</em> hadn't received the same treatment when it released in October of 2014. The third was&nbsp;<em>Dynasty Warriors 8 Empires</em>, the final mainline entry in the series available for Vita.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-9.jpg"/></p>
<p>Two last surprises were lined up for 2015, the first being&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/sid-meiers-civilization-revolution-2-multi-language/13/709c2d">Civilization Revolution 2 Plus</a></em> from 2K Games, which was a shock for a number of reasons. The publisher had barely touched Vita previously and although it wasn't a surprise to see the title available in English (it was originally announced for Japan), it was noteworthy that Asia would be getting its own physical English print when it was only going to be available digitally in the west. Meanwhile, as with&nbsp;<em>Moe Chronicle</em>, Cygames'&nbsp;<em>Airship Q</em> saw an Asian-English only release <a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/airship-q-japanese/13/709a91">in November</a>,&nbsp;which offered a nice alternative to the digging and crafting of&nbsp;<em>Terraria</em> for importers, albeit with slightly less polish to the package.</p>
<p>These marked a fantastic note to end the year on - the market had clearly grown and flourished in 2015, but it was 2016 that would be absolutely stellar.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>2016 - An Amazing Year for Importers</strong></span></p>
<p>By 2016, multiple publishers were making full use of the Asian-English market to not only release physical versions of games that were digital-only in the west, but also to localize titles which weren't seeing overseas releases at all.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-7.jpg"/></p>
<p>The year kicked off with the launch of&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/deemo-the-last-recital-chinese-english-subs/13/709hgp">Deemo: The Last Recital</a></em>, a story-driven rhythm game from Rayark that had launched in Japan in the middle of 2015. At the time, it was the only English Vita version available, though the game later launched in North America and Europe thanks to PM Studios in 2017. The game itself was a decently fun time, although a little bit too grindy for <a  href="https://kresnik258gaming.wordpress.com/2016/06/21/vita-deemo-the-last-recital-import-review/">me personally</a>.</p>
<p>February saw two major releases from Bandai-Namco - both were games which were available digitally in the west, but the only physical English copies were in Asia. The first of these was&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/digimon-story-cyber-sleuth-english/13/709my1">Digimon Story: Cyber Sleuth</a>,</em> which had also been ported to PS4, although the Vita version remained an impressive technical feat (which I personally enjoyed a lot <a  href="https://kresnik258gaming.wordpress.com/2017/12/22/vita-digimon-story-cyber-sleuth-review/">when I played it</a>). The second was&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/mobile-suit-gundam-extreme-vs-force-english/13/7097jl">Mobile Suit Gundam: Extreme Vs Force</a></em>, the latest in the long-running&nbsp;<em>Gundam Vs</em> series that received a <a  href="http://www.siliconera.com/2015/12/23/gundam-extreme-vs-force-is-getting-plasma-blasted-by-amazon-reviews-in-japan/">critical beating in Japan</a>, although this was somewhat resolved for its English version. A western release of the latter didn't actually happen until July of 2017 (five whole months after the Asian-English version).</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-6.png"/></p>
<p>By far the most noteworthy release of the year came in March with&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/dead-or-alive-xtreme-3-venus-multi-language/13/709dv9">Dead or Alive Xtreme 3: Venus</a>.&nbsp;</em>The title courted minor controversy due to its content and Team Ninja quickly announced that it <a  href="http://www.kotaku.co.uk/2015/11/24/why-the-next-dead-or-alive-xtreme-beach-volleyball-game-wont-leave-japan">wouldn't be coming west at all</a>&nbsp;due to concerns about the potential social implications of its message, making the Asian version the only possible way of playing in English. It seems like it was still successful though, as Play-Asia announced that the game had become its most <a  href="https://www.dualshockers.com/ps4ps-vita-exclusive-dead-or-alive-xtreme-3-breaks-sales-record-at-play-asia/">pre-ordered title ever</a>, breaking sales records for the retailer.</p>
<p>In addition to&nbsp;<em>Dead or Alive</em>, it seems that other franchises weren't afraid to only target the Asian-English market too. Despite&nbsp;<em>Extreme Vs Force</em> seeing a western digital release in July, the next&nbsp;<em>Gundam&nbsp;</em>title -&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/gundam-breaker-3-english-subs/13/709u4t">Breaker 3</a></em> - wasn't afforded the same opportunity, likely due to ongoing licensing issues with certain mechs in the game. In fact, this wasn't the only time that a&nbsp;<em>Gundam&nbsp;</em>title would exclusively see a release in Asia in 2017, as&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/sd-gundam-g-generation-genesis-english-subs/13/70a0nd">SD Gundam G Generation Genesis</a></em> suffered the same fate in November and notably became the first (and only) Vita game with two game carts required for playing.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-4.jpg"/></p>
<p>The rest of the year was made up of the usual selection of titles already available from North American and European publishers such as <em>Sword Art Online: Hollow Realization</em> (which had now become a notable worldwide franchise for Bandai-Namco after&nbsp;<em>Hollow Fragment's&nbsp;</em>sales success). Two additional releases also stood out.&nbsp;<a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/aw-phoenix-festa-english-subs/13/70ab1d"><em>A.W. Phoenix Festa</em></a>&nbsp;was another anime tie-in without the same budget as the&nbsp;<em>SAO</em> games - it received a muted western reception but seemed to get a little more fanfare in Asia. Meanwhile&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/dragon-quest-builders-alefgard-o-fukkatsu-seyo-english/13/70ah4z">Dragon Quest Builders</a></em> was one of the Vita's <a  href="https://kresnik258gaming.wordpress.com/2018/02/17/vita-dragon-quest-builders-review/">stand-out titles</a> of fall 2016, with a physical version that could only be found in Asia.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>2017 - Business as Usual</strong></span></p>
<p>At this point it was clear that, despite the Vita's relative failure in the west, the Asian-English market was successful enough for multiple publishers to jump on board. And not only were they serving the countries the games released in, but importers would often jump on these titles too. 2017 would continue these trends, although in slightly reduced capacity.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-3.jpg"  width="640"  height="360"/></p>
<p>The first release of the year was&nbsp;<a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/super-robot-wars-v-english-subs/13/70a98h"><em>Super Robot Wars V</em></a> in February, the latest in a long line of crossover strategy RPGs. The Vita had seen two Japan-only entries in 2014 and 2015, but from 2016 there seemed to have been a change of heart, with the PS3/PS4 entry&nbsp;<em>Moon Dwellers</em> getting an Asian-English version. This continued with&nbsp;<em>V</em>, which again never managed to find its way west, meaning importing was the only way to go (as with&nbsp;<em>Moon Dwellers</em>).</p>
<p>In fact, 2017 would be a very busy year for Bandai-Namco as it had a further two releases during the early months of the year. The first of these was&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/accel-world-vs-sword-art-online-english-subs/13/70b4kt">Accel World vs. Sword Art Online</a></em>, the final in the&nbsp;<em>SAO&nbsp;</em>series on Vita and - just as it had started with&nbsp;<em>Hollow Fragment</em> - this was a title where the only physical English Vita version was available in Asia (an oddly fitting way to go out). The second was&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/gundam-breaker-3-break-edition-english-subs/13/70b3uv">Gundam Breaker 3: Break Edition</a></em>, one of only a handful of 'game-of-the-year' editions on Vita that included all the DLC on the cart.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-2.jpg"/></p>
<p>Outside of Bandai-Namco's efforts the year was quiet. Koei-Tecmo had now given up on Vita, but other publishers were entering the fray - notably eastasiasoft who took up the mantle of handling physical releases for a variety of indie games. Titles like&nbsp;<em>Semispheres</em> and&nbsp;<em>Tachyon Project</em> were on their slate, both of which were digital-only in the west. Arc System Works also picked up Nihon Falcom's classic action-RPG&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/ys-origin-multi-language/13/70aylx">Ys Origin</a></em>, which was a nice bonus for physical collectors (even if Limited Run Games had also picked up the game for an American release).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>2018 - This Train Isn't Stopping Yet!</strong></span></p>
<p>So with the current year well underway, where does that leave us with Asian-English games? Well, in short they still seem to be flowing like usual, even at this late stage in Vita's life. In fact even some new publishers are now joining in.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-5.jpg"/></p>
<p>The start of the year seems to have been a recap of previous successes -&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/digimon-story-cyber-sleuth-hackers-memory-english/13/70bqvv">Digimon Story: Cyber Sleuth Hacker's Memory</a></em> and&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://sea.play-asia.com/super-robot-wars-x-english-subs/13/70bs19">Super Robot Wars X</a></em>, both sequels to existing Vita games which got Asian-English versions, made up the significant titles for the first couple of months. Again,&nbsp;<em>Digimon</em> was digital-only in the west while&nbsp;<em>Super Robot Wars</em> seems to be a title that's remaining Asia-only, likely meaning it'll be popular with importers who enjoyed what&nbsp;<em>V</em> had to offer.</p>
<p>In a surprise announcement, it was also revealed that we'd be getting&nbsp;<em><a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/bullet-girls-phantasia-multi-language/13/70beob">Bullet Girls Phantasia</a>&nbsp;-&nbsp;</em>the latest in the popular clothes-ripping shooting franchise - from a partnership between D3 Publisher and H2 Interactive. Play-Asia seems to have been <a  href="https://www.play-asia.com/blog/2017/12/12/ecchi-history-bullet-girls-phantasia/">promoting the game heavily</a>, suggesting the retailer expects it to be as successful as&nbsp;<em>Dead or Alive Xtreme 3</em> was in 2016.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/vita-asian-english-1.jpg"/></p>
<p>Sadly, not every title got an Asian-English release that perhaps should have.&nbsp;<em>Gintama Rumble</em>, a hack 'n' slash take on the long-running anime/manga series developed by Tamsoft was announced for both PS4 &amp; Vita in Japan, but an English version for Asia was announced <a  href="https://gematsu.com/2017/07/gintama-project-last-game-ps4-coming-asia-english">only for PS4</a>. It was a surprising omission given that the game was published by Bandai-Namco, which is clearly intending to support the Vita in the region throughout 2018.</p>
<p>Still, overall 2018 looks to be another great year for importers and this is only from known titles - there's plenty of time for new games to be announced in the remaining months too.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>Conclusion</strong></span></p>
<p>Compared to how it was when the Vita launched in 2011, the Asian-English market of 2018 is a booming business, with multiple publishers investing in releasing titles either exclusively in the region or as the only physical versions available. A number of retailers now specialize in this area too, with shops like <a  href="http://buygame2.com/en/">Buygame2</a>,<a  href="http://heavyarm-asia.com/">Heavy-Arm</a>,<a  href="https://mariio128.com/">Mariio128</a>, and <a  href="http://play-asia.com/">Play-Asia</a> focusing on courting importers.</p>
<p>It's hard to deny that Vita had a big hand in starting this. It was Bandai-Namco which took a gamble on&nbsp;<em>Sword Art Online: Hollow Fragment</em> back in 2014 that kicked it all off, with the Vita fanbase embracing this new method of game delivery and importing the title in droves, leading to some heavy investment in the market from Bandai-Namco which ultimately caused other publishers to follow suit. Throw in the ease of releasing physical versions in the region in general (meaning games were available on carts where they wouldn't be elsewhere) and you've got an area that continues to see success stories to this day.</p>
<p>While the remainder of Vita's life is up in the air at this point thanks to the Switch's runaway success, I'm hopeful that the Asian-English market will provide a nice final bastion for physical collectors, as well provide us with a couple more surprises along the way. Companies like Kadokawa Games could leverage it to deliver physical versions of titles such as&nbsp;<em>The Lost Child</em> which are digital-only in the west, while questionably lewd games like&nbsp;<em>Moero Pirates</em> would make perfect sense to translate to English in the region for Compile Heart.</p>
<p>No matter what happens, though, my collection of Vita game cases has been fantastically bolstered by the Asian-English market and I'm incredibly grateful for the future-proofing (and memory card space-saving) it has provided me with along the way.</p><p>Full Article - <a href="http://www.vgchartz.com/article/272598/a-look-back-at-the-birth-amp-rise-of-the-asian-english-market-on-vita/">http://www.vgchartz.com/article/272598/a-look-back-at-the-birth-amp-rise-of-the-asian-english-market-on-vita/</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/VGChartz/~4/xLfKGyqBGUg" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

        <description><p>&nbsp;Matt Makes Games'&nbsp;<em>Celeste&nbsp;</em>is a triumph, in every sense of the word. This is a truly special game that captures the true and impressionistic beauty of the old bit era and all it has to offer. Not since Yacht Club Games'&nbsp;<em>Shovel Knight</em>&nbsp;has this style of&nbsp;game&nbsp;been&nbsp;so wonderfully realized. What made&nbsp;<em>Shovel Knight</em>&nbsp;so good was the character movement and slow mastery (and therefore sense of accomplishment) of those movements in order to advance through the levels, and&nbsp;<em>Celeste&nbsp;</em>somehow manages to surpass it on these fronts.&nbsp;</p>
<div><img  src="/articles_media/images/celeste-screens-2.jpg"/></div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>I cannot express how important movement can be in a game and how otherwise good titles can be ruined by a lack of concern on the developer&rsquo;s part for making this element enjoyable. Thankfully, <em>Celeste</em> is one of the most pleasant games I have experienced in this respect. It's difficult and you will die... hundreds of times (I died over 1,000 times by the time I completed it), but you respawn so quickly and the checkpoints are so frequent that you rarely get frustrated, and on the occasions you do this feeling quickly goes away when you finally break through the next checkpoint and feel an enormous sense of satisfaction.</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>In <em>Celeste</em> you hop, wall jump, double jump, and bounce off of objects all the way to the end of each world in typical platforming fashion. Every world is divided into dozens of individual screens you have to get through (let's call them levels for ease of understanding). Rarely does one get through a level without dying at least&nbsp;once. Indeed, often times you will need to jump so far away in order to move your screen perspective (so that you can see where you need to go to next) that you'll&nbsp;intentionally kill yourself.</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>Some levels have a handy little character that will let you move your camera around so that you know what to anticipate and can strategize, but for the most&nbsp;part&nbsp;you're going to just have to take the plunge. Most levels can be completed after a couple attempts, but some are really tricky; there were quite a few that killed me dozens of times before I managed to figure them out. At least in those moments I could take solace in the fact that I usually came a little closer to the end and died in&nbsp;<em>Super Smash Bros.&nbsp;</em>fashion, with explosions off-screen.</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div><img  src="/articles_media/images/celeste-screens-3.jpg"/></div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>Towards the end of the <em>Celeste</em>, just when you've finally gotten to grips with the difficult jumping system, a new type of movement will unlock and this makes the game even more enjoyable to play. It's amazing how pleasant the double jump is to use, and the fact that you unlock it with a story progression component after hours of deaths makes it all the more satisfying. You might think, as a reader not having played the game, that unlocking the second jump wouldn't be that big of a deal, but the whole game is based on pitch-perfect timing so it really is; it's like&nbsp;<em>Donkey Kong</em>&nbsp;on steroids in terms of jump timing.</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>The only thing more impressive than the gameplay mechanics is the story. I have never, in the 70-80 games I&rsquo;ve reviewed to-date, experienced a text-based NES/SNES bit game as incredibly emotionally moving as this one. <em>Celeste</em> follows the story of an anxious girl who needs a break from the real world; one who I honestly thought may have had a bipolar disorder. As a special education teacher I was impressed by the game's representation of a group of people that are hardly ever represented in art (be it movies, music, or video games).</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div><img  src="/articles_media/images/celeste-screens-1.jpg"/></div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>In order to have you fully understand the meaning of what I'm about to say I need to make it clear that I'm not often emotionally moved by video games. Certainly, I cannot remember ever having shed a tear over one. I shed tears while playing this game. It's so overwhelming to see how much despair the central character goes through; all the self-doubt, the anxiety, the pleading for help in the most desperate of ways, the giving up entirely.</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>All of these things are accompanied by a soundtrack that perfectly - and I mean perfectly - fits the tone of those moments; I felt all of the sadness that she felt. I know quite a few people in my life that struggle with anxiety (friends and students) and to see this so convincingly shown in a game hit me hard. I myself felt depressed through certain parts, but I kept pushing on because I had a gut feeling about something.</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>That feeling was that this game wasn&rsquo;t about realizing the misery of life, but the beauty&nbsp;within&nbsp;the&nbsp;misery,&nbsp;and my gut turned out to be correct. I have no intention of ruining some of the game&rsquo;s best characters and scenes with specifics, but after a long time of hiking up the mountain, and despite all of your self-doubts, eventually there is a major setback. But in that moment our protagonist finally finds her inner strength and peace, and manages to press on in what is one of the most emotionally charged scenes I have ever experienced in a video game.</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div><img  src="/articles_media/images/celeste-screens-6.jpg"/></div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>All of these scenes, from the funny ones to the dark, scary ones, to the sad ones, to the joyful ones, are connected with music the likes of which one rarely hears in a video game. I remember the first time your 'twin' appears and the dark music kicks in - soon after that my expectations for the game quickly went from "this seems like a decent enough indie game" to "oh my goodness this may be the best indie game I've ever played."</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>Music is so very important and is often undervalued or ignored completely in reviews. I could literally listen to the soundtrack of <em>Interstellar</em> without hearing any of the movie's dialogue and probably be moved just as much if not more. Music is even more crucial in a game that doesn't actually have voice dialogue, and <em>Celeste</em> is all text all of the time, except for some strange noises the characters make as the dialogue is presented.</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div><img  src="/articles_media/images/celeste-extra-shot-1.jpg"/></div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>Still, there are a couple flaws. If you love a challenge then this is a title for you, but each 'level' is short and is basically a checkpoint in itself. As you move off-screen into another screen (or level) your progress is saved. Towards the end of the game there are more and more checkpoints, but not because the game is divided into multiple screens, but rather a few large ones that contain very difficult jumps. Personally, I loved these checkpoints, but I understand not everyone will appreciate the change in how they're distributed towards the end.</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>On the other hand some levels require an enormous amount of deaths before you'll figure things out - which by itself is fine - but this will sometimes be because you can't adjust the camera angle to anticipate upcoming sections, which can be incredibly frustrating and will feel a little unfair at times.</div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div><img  src="/articles_media/images/celeste-screens-4.jpg"/></div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div><em>Celeste</em> isn't perfect, but that's fitting because the story is about an imperfect protagonist. But it's undoubtedly an incredible game; one you're unlikely to forget thanks to its heavy hitting tones and the absolute resolve of its protagonist who never gives in to the temptation of apathy and despair.&nbsp;</div><p>Full Article - <a href="http://www.vgchartz.com/article/272569/celeste-ns/">http://www.vgchartz.com/article/272569/celeste-ns/</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/VGChartz/~4/v7IheAi-yD0" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

        <title><![CDATA[The Longest Five Minutes (NS)]]></title>
        <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/VGChartz/~3/9YN4w_Um_7A/</link>

        <description><p>What would it be like to experience a game that started you at the end boss? And what if your hero didn't even remember who they were when facing said boss? Developer Nippon Ichi Software and NIS America seek to answer these questions with this quirky retro-style RPG, <em>The Longest Five Minutes</em>. It's a game that takes the typical RPG formula and turns it on its head; well, in some respects anyway.</p>
<p><em>The Longest Five Minute</em>s is, on one level, a nostalgic homage to the 8 bit RPGs of yesteryear with its colorful pixel art and basic mechanics, yet it paradoxically adds some innovative elements that provide a breath of fresh air. Unfortunately though, the game never quite excels in either of these aspects. It offers little of substance outside its memorable narrative and interesting characters, and its basic retro aesthetic comes off more as stock than nostalgic or charming.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/longest-five-minute-new-2-1.jpg"/></p>
<p>As simplistic as the visuals look, the gameplay is even moreso. <em>The Longest Five Minutes</em> in fact goes so minimal on the gameplay side that it verges on being an interactive visual novel, albeit an decent one. The battle system is even simple enough to essentially play itself, as you can select pre-determined styles of automatic moves, emphasizing attacks, spells, or healing. Then it&rsquo;s a matter of holding the &ldquo;a&rdquo; button during the brief, randomly generated battle as the game does its thing.</p>
<p><em>The Longest Five Minutes</em> is so easy that you rarely have to worry about fighting manually and implementing real strategy. As long as you grind a bit and buy a few decent upgrades to equip, it's smooth sailing, since you typically overpower your foes by a wide margin. In fact, I only died a couple of times during my entire run, one of which was a particularly difficult boss fight that I somewhat rushed to get to. There were quite a few moments like this during my playthrough in which I couldn't help but ask, &ldquo;well, what&rsquo;s the point?&rdquo;</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/longest-five-minute-new-2-5.jpg"/></p>
<p>To its credit, the game does provide some more appeal and depth to its story. It embraces a unique and interesting formula in terms of its narrative and progression that defies traditional linear structure. You essentially begin at the end boss - the Demon King - and play your way back in the form of a drawn-out stretch of 5 minute flashbacks. You find you have no memory of who you or your friends are, how you ended up here, or why your going blow to blow with this menacing demon. You eventually come full circle and remember the events and circumstances that led you to this climax.</p>
<p>These memories take the form of a few dozen bite-sized segments which range from 5 minute fetch quests to half hour dungeon crawls, many of which contain watered-down versions of those <em>Pokemon</em> Gameboy puzzles. Each flashback contains a main objective and sometimes sprinkles in a couple of basic sidequests for bonus xp, reeling you back to the final boss battle upon completion. You'll occasionally be posed choices as to how you go about attacking the boss with text prompts, like a choose-your-own-adventure.</p>
<p>This formula certainly makes <em>The Longest Five Minutes</em> an ideal fit for the on-the-go Switch player, who may only have, say, a 40 minute train ride to burn through a couple of quests and take out that miniboss atop the tower. It can also be a liberating experience to zip across completely different scenes of the game and gain power so quickly. Yet these bits of gameplay tend to feel disjointed, as they jump you around to so many different points in the story, and there isn't much that connects them. This is true in terms of progression as well - as the game resets your cash, weapons, and armor at the start of each memory. You'll find that you've often leapt 10-20 levels higher and have been granted additional spells too.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/longest-five-minute-new-2-2.jpg"/></p>
<p>Thus, despite the interesting plot, I struggled to be fully invested in many of my trips down memory lane, as I was essentially "fast forwarding" through my hero's experience. It&rsquo;s also tough to be motivated to really deck out your character because their gear is going to be completely changed during the following memory anyway. The only real consistent element of progression is what&rsquo;s referred to as &ldquo;re-experience points,&rdquo; which carries over from one memory to the next.</p>
<p>To be fair, these odd dynamics do make sense within the context of the story - and I <em>did</em> enjoy the narrative overall, despite my relative indifference to game stories as a whole. There is plenty of drama, suspense, and humor throughout, along with some neat plot twists and revelations to keep you at least curious enough to press on. As you progress, you learn more and more about who you are, your true purpose, and the origin of the Demon King, along with a malevolent fog which plagues the lands and turns all in its path into demons.</p>
<p>Even inanimate objects aren't safe from this fog, which makes for some amusing battles as you go head-to-head against the likes of possessed wine barrels and killer trains. As you might expect, then, the game never takes itself too seriously despite some profound and dark moments. On top of some comical baddies, our heroes speak plenty of quips and engage in whimsical exchanges you might find in your typical light-hearted anime.</p>
<p><img  src="/articles_media/images/longest-five-minute-new-2-4.jpg"/></p>
<p>The plot certainly keeps you somewhat engaged with its likable cast of characters, and the fact that we're uncovering details right along with our protagonist allows us to connect on some level. With all this said, there is an abundance of mindless chatter among both our heroes and a majority of the NPCs that contribute little, if anything, to the plot. Even by RPG standards, the amount of pointless text can be excessive. Still, the game at least hints at some enriching world building and cool fantasy themes in the background that invoke the imagination.</p>
<p>As a whole, I quite liked the <em>The Longest Five Minutes</em>&rsquo; themes and concepts in theory; the idea of rediscovering ones self through memories, &ldquo;the past affecting the present&rdquo; through in-game choices, and the dark fantasy overlay. It&rsquo;s just that all this potential feels largely unrealized and hardly fleshed out in the way it could have been. There isn&rsquo;t a large diversity of choices that impact play during your battle with the Demon King, or in general for that matter. There also aren't really notable instances of memories directly <em>affecting</em> this battle, which the game seems to imply. Still, if you're fond of oldschool 8 bit JRPGs ala <em>Pokemon</em>, <em>Dragon Quest</em>, and <em>Earthbound</em>, and enjoy a relatively rich story with your games, you might get more out of <em>The Longest Five Minutes</em>. Just don&rsquo;t expect a rich and hearty RPG meal - this is more of a small platter of bite-sized appetizers.</p><p>Full Article - <a href="http://www.vgchartz.com/article/272582/the-longest-five-minutes-ns/">http://www.vgchartz.com/article/272582/the-longest-five-minutes-ns/</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/VGChartz/~4/9YN4w_Um_7A" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

        <link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/VGChartz/~3/6bFZp17JROo/</link>

        <category><![CDATA[Charts]]></category>

        <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.vgchartz.com/story/272577/vgchartzs-top-50-video-game-soundtracks-40-31/</guid>
        <description><p>Welcome to part two of our top 50 video game soundtracks countdown. This time we'll be covering the games from #40 to #31, but before we get to that I think it's time to quickly look at the first batch of honourable mentions. These are some of the games that just barely missed out on the top 50, but which still deserve to be recognized for their exceptional music.</p>
<p ><a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NoBRdekWKxI"><strong>The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess (Composers: Toru Minegishi and Asuka Ohta)</strong></a></p>
<p><em>Twilight Princess </em>is the 5<span >th</span>&nbsp;highest ranking&nbsp;<em>Zelda </em>title on the list and the second that didn't make it into the top 50. Still, the score is of the usual high quality fans have come to expect from <em>The Legend of Zelda, </em>and being #59 out of 339 games isn't a bad result at all.</p>
<p ><a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q6IPtRIDzoA"><strong>Child of Light (Composer: B&eacute;atrice Martin)</strong></a></p>
<p>The score in <em>Child of Light </em>differentiates itself from most other games by being beautifully understated and melancholy in tone. The game's quiet atmosphere seeps through every facet of its music, and definitely deserves to be mentioned here. If you haven't done so yet, check it out.</p>
<p ><a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-LYB7iLZNWE"><strong>Sonic the Hedgehog 2 (Composer: Masato Nakamura)</strong></a></p>
<p>This is the highest ranked <em>Sonic </em>game from the voting, losing out on the top 50 by a mere 3 points. It's an excellent score, produced on a console that is not as often mentioned when it comes to soundtrack discussions, especially in comparison to its competition at the time.</p>
<p>That's it for the first part of the honourable mentions, next time we'll cover a few more, but for now, let's continue with the main countdown. If you haven't seen the first part yet, you can check it out <a  href="/article/272432/vgchartzs-top-50-video-game-soundtracks-50-41/">here</a>.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>#40 Nier </strong></span></p>
<p ><span ><strong>(Composers: Keiichi Okabe, Kakeru Ishihama, Keiho Hoashi and Takafumi Nishimura) </strong></span></p>
<p >&nbsp;</p>
<p>Yoko Taro has always had a talent for creating games with beautifully melancholic atmospheres and bittersweet stories that constantly manage to take the player by surprise, tackling subjects and themes that most other developers often wouldn't even think about delving into. In <em>NieR</em> one of the most important elements in bringing the tone and themes of the game to the forefront and emphasizing their importance is the music.</p>
<p>The soundtrack consists largely of acoustic pieces with vocals sung by Emi Evans. Evans wrote her own lyrics for the game in a fictional language made specifically for this title, and was inspired by a number of different real world languages such as Gaelic, French, Japanese, and Spanish, among others. Tracks like &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MdZNYbn7OuM">Emil/Karma</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aeYqTwVgt7A">Hills of Radiant Winds</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=viDKam_hmGM">Kaine/Salvation</a>&acute;, and &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WEOaWX_TFLE">Temple of Drifting Sands</a>&acute; are a good place to start listening, but the entire soundtrack is worth going out of your way to experience in full.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>#39 Doom (2016) </strong></span></p>
<p ><span ><strong>(Composer: Mick Gordon)</strong></span></p>
<p ><strong><br /></strong></p>
<p>In many ways the new <em>Doom </em>is basically a loving tribute to the originals of the 90s. Even when it modernizes elements that made the original <em>Doom</em> so&nbsp;great 25 years ago, it is still instantly recognizable as a <em>Doom</em>&nbsp;title, and the music plays a big part in achieving that. Mick Gordon set out to create a score that would not only work by itself within the reboot, but also serve as a homage to the original's soundtrack, and in my opinion he achieved this goal flawlessly.</p>
<p>There are no shortage of exceptional tracks in the score, but some of the best examples in my view are &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zZMg9ryeWOw&amp;t=">Rip &amp; Tear</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9XYZXqOiNoM&amp;t=">VEGA Core</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XeYGdZSt5l0&amp;t=">Mastermind</a>&acute;, and &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b2YG8DX0ees&amp;t=">Harbinger</a>&acute;.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>#38 Kingdom Hearts 2 </strong></span></p>
<p ><span ><strong>(Composer: Yoko Shimomura)</strong></span></p>
<p ></p>
<p>There are comparatively few female composers working in the video game industry, but perhaps the best example of an excellent one is Yoko Shimomura, who over the last 30 years has composed music for a huge number of games, including the likes of <em>Super Mario RPG, Parasite Eve, Legend of Mana, Final Fantasy XV, </em>and many others. Over that time she has also developed an instantly recognizable sound present in nearly all of her work.</p>
<p>Yoko Shimomura&nbsp;is likely best known for her work on the <em>Kingdom Hearts&nbsp;</em>series, and the second main entry has some of her best compositions ever. Shimomura's scores have a tendency be highly varied, with numerous different genres represented in them, and <em>Kingdom Hearts II </em>is no different on that front. Tracks like &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hs5ZG5mhmtI">Reviving Hollow Bastion</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4g2MF4Hgdfk">Organization XIII</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fO90T_ARqUA">Hazardous Highway</a>&acute;, and &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rhyRoaMw4RU">Sacred Moon</a>&acute; show off this great variety perfectly.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>#37 Metal Gear Solid </strong></span></p>
<p ><span ><strong>(Composers: Kazuki Muraoka, Hiroyuki Togo, Takanari Ishiyama, Lee Jeon Myung, Maki Kirioka, Tappi Iwase and Rika Muranaka)</strong></span></p>
<p >&nbsp;</p>
<p>When it comes to the music in the <em>Metal Gear Solid&nbsp;</em>games, arguments can be made for each in regards to which of them has the best soundtrack in the series. However, on VGC there was no question as to which of them was the favourite, with the original <em>Metal Gear Solid </em>being listed more often than any other entry.</p>
<p>The score for the game was composed by a team of Konami's in-house musicians, perhaps most notably Tappi Iwase, who was responsible for the iconic &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tAKi13Gb7es&amp;t">Metal Gear Solid Main Theme</a>&acute;, and Rika Muranaka, who wrote the game's main vocal theme &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t1bzqjoZyeQ">The Best Is Yet To Come</a>&acute;. The music that plays during gameplay moments, such as &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wn-ht6qU2_s">Rex's Lair</a>&acute;, has an almost industrial feel, while the cutscene music is much more cinematic in style, as heard in the track &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pi429iYzYpM">Introduction</a>&acute;, for example.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>#36 Bastion </strong></span></p>
<p ><span ><strong>(Composer: Darren Korb)</strong></span></p>
<p >&nbsp;</p>
<p>Supergiant Games, the studio behind <em>Transistor, Pyre&nbsp;</em>and, of course, <em>Bastion, </em>has one very specific talent that often separates its work from that of other developers, namely the skill to marry gameplay, story, and music together in such a way that each complements the other two. <em>Bastion </em>was the team's first game, but even from the very beginning the company's use of music in conjunction with every scene and moment in the game was masterful.</p>
<p><em>Bastion's</em> most well-known theme is likely &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jz8c17upEwM">Build That Wall</a>&acute;, with vocals by Ashley Lynn Barrett, but the entire soundtrack is filled with great songs. It relies heavily on acoustic instruments, and this can be heard in tracks such as &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-jU9EFTMhbY">In Case of Trouble</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=39U4Y09ewWU">Twisted Streets</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7eqMszMGUww">Spike In a Rail</a>&acute;, and the beautiful ending theme, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDflVhOpS4E">Setting Sail, Coming Home</a>&acute;, which combines two of the game's earlier vocal tracks into a duet.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>#35 Xenoblade Chronicles 2 </strong></span></p>
<p ><span ><strong>(Composers: Yasunori Mitsuda, ACE, Kenji Hiramatsu and Manami Kiyota)</strong></span></p>
<p ><strong><br /></strong></p>
<p>The first of four 2017 releases on this list, <em>Xenoblade Chronicles 2 </em>was notable for its inclusion of Yasunori Mitsuda as the game's main composer. He had previously provided the ending theme for the first <em>Xenoblade Chronicles,</em> but was now in charge of the entire soundtrack, including the audio budget and recording schedule. Working together with a team of composers, Mitsuda ultimately created around 25 of the 120 tracks composed for the title.</p>
<p>Although Mitsuda's style is definitely different from the music found in the first game, thanks to ACE and the rest of the composers it still sounds like a <em>Xenoblade </em>game. Regardless of the style, however, the score is excellent, with each contributing composer providing some great pieces. A few tracks I would recommend are &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=olksNCk3oBg">Fonsa Myma (Night)</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZQ9xfbJ5Tbs">Where We Used To Be</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Gd_pdQhqMc">The Ancient Vessel</a>&acute;, and the &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0cNmgwQHgR4">Unique Monster Battle Theme</a>&acute;.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>#34 The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild </strong></span></p>
<p ><span ><strong>(Composers: Manaka Kataoka and Yasuaki Iwata)</strong></span></p>
<p ><strong><br /></strong></p>
<p>The score for <em>The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild </em>was somewhat divisive among series fans. Some loved the new, more ambient style of music, while others said it didn't sound like <em>Zelda </em>at all, missing the melodic and generally more upbeat style found in most previous titles in the franchise. Much of this new sound was thanks to the two composers - Manaki Kataoka and Yasuaki Iwata.</p>
<p>Kataoka had previously only worked on one <em>Zelda </em>game, namely <em>Spirit Tracks, </em>while Iwata actually had just two prior Nintendo games to his name in general. Many of the tracks are quite minimalistic as well, often only featuring one or two instruments in total, as the game tends to let the sounds of the environment itself take over. Still, there are certainly a number of beautiful tracks to be found here as well. A few recommended pieces would be &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IhdibdC4azQ">Stables</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R4ZkklcIfTo">Prince Sidon's Theme</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YcI_aRfSaHI&amp;t">Zora's Domain (Day)</a>&acute; and &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9G6088FtGsI">Attack On Vah Ruta</a>&acute;.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>#33 EarthBound </strong></span></p>
<p ><span ><strong>(Composers: Keiichi Tanaka and Hirokazu Tanaka) </strong></span></p>
<p >&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<p>This is quite possibly the most eclectic of all the soundtracks in this top 50, which to be fair fits perfectly within the context of <em>EarthBound. </em>The score took influence from a massive number of different bands and artists, and even directly references many classical and folk songs. Tanaka actually composed over 100 tracks for the game, but naturally most of them weren't actually used due to the SNES cartridge's memory limitations.</p>
<p>The composers have cited artists and bands such as The Beach Boys, John Lennon, Frank Zappa, and many others as having influenced the music in <em>EarthBound. </em>Overall the score, while highly varied, does lean heavily towards jazz music with many of its tracks. It is quite unlike any other video game score I can think of - in a good way. The music almost seems to delight in not doing what one would expect it to, going in weird directions and taking sudden shifts in tone, sometimes even becoming genuinely disturbing. You can hear this yourself in tracks like &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7y5RRgjfNek&amp;t">Onett Theme</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-ptrVQJT5Wc">Battle Against a Weird Opponent</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TKvjEQXKeec">Sanctuary Guardian</a>&acute;, and &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NLWWkeajPKE">The Lost Underworld</a>&acute;.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>#32 The Last of Us </strong></span></p>
<p ><span ><strong>(Composers: Gustavo Santaolalla, Andrew Buresh, Jonathan Mayer and Anthony Caruso)</strong>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p ><strong><br /></strong></p>
<p>The decision to hire Gustavo Santaolalla to compose the original score for <em>The Last of Us </em>came about when Neil Druckmann and Bruce Straley realized that a lot of the music they had been compiling as an inspiration for the game's score has been composed by Santaolalla. They felt his style would be perfect for the game's narrative and setting, and after hearing what the title was all about Santaolalla agreed to compose the soundtrack.</p>
<p>Overall it's actually quite low-key, even during the game's action sections, fitting the sombre apocalyptic setting. If I had to describe the score's overall tone, it would be beautiful and quiet melancholy. Many tracks also have a certain unsettling quality to them, sounding just slightly out of tune. The score is filled with excellent pieces, but tracks like &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8p2DjSwt4_g">The Last of Us</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wjs6RAfrd60">The Path</a>&acute; and &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OhzxITEb5wE">The Way It Was</a>&acute; are a good place to start listening.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p ><span ><strong>#31 Dark Souls </strong></span></p>
<p ><span ><strong>(Composer: Motoi Sakuraba)</strong></span></p>
<p >&nbsp;</p>
<p>One of the biggest surprises I had in regards to <em>Dark Souls </em>was realizing that its music was composed by Motoi Sakuraba. His usual style, found in series like <em>Tales </em>and <em>Star Ocean, </em>is so different from his work in <em>Dark Souls </em>that I never would have guessed he was behind it. Yet he was, and the end result is quite possibly the best overall score he has ever created.</p>
<p>While the compositions in the soundtrack vary from quiet piano pieces to bombastic symphonic themes, there's always an undercurrent of sadness and feeling of finality in practically every one of the game's music tracks. The score perfectly complements the decaying world of Lordran, filling every moment with a sense of foreboding and danger, as if you're always just one step away from certain death. Tracks like &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nsps0I58yUM">Ornstein &amp; Smough</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GbYGXYmOF8k">Crossbreed Priscilla</a>&acute;, &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wNvujJEQ864">Dark Sun Gwndolin</a>&acute;, and &acute;<a  href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AB6sOhQan9Y">Gwyn, Lord of Cinder</a>&acute; all embody this wonderfully.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>One particularly cool feature that&rsquo;s part of the software included with each Nintendo Labo kit is Toy-Con Garage, which can be accessed in Discover mode. <p>In addition to Toy-Con Garage, the Toy-Con projects in each kit offer numerous ways to have fun as you Make, Play and Discover different experiences.</p>
<p><strong>Robot Kit:</strong></p>

<li>Build your own wearable Toy-Con Robot suit and assume control of a giant in-game robot, completing challenges and destroying in-game objects to unlock powerful new abilities.</li>
<li>If you&rsquo;re feeling competitive, you can even challenge a friend in two-player local battles or compare your high scores/rankings with other players! (An additional Robot Kit and Joy-Con controllers are required for two-player mode; sold separately.)</li>
<li>Nintendo Labo encourages you to use your imagination and creativity to customize your cardboard Toy-Con creations in a variety of ways. The Robot Kit even allows you to customize and level-up your in-game robot.</li>
